facts.text: On 6th April 1951, the appellant transported 15 maunds of juwar from his village of Khanjroli to Mandvi without a permit, contravening section 5(1) of the Bombay Food Grains Regulation of Movement and Sale Order, 1949.

Resident First Class Magistrate of Bardoli tried the case, found appellant guilty under section 7 of the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act No. XXIV of 1946, sentenced to imprisonment till the rising of the Court and fine of Rs. 500.
Conviction and sentence affirmed by Sessions Judge, Surat, on appeal.

Appellant filed revision petition in High Court of Bombay (Criminal Revision Application No. 642 of 1952), raising for first time objection that Resident First Class Magistrate had no jurisdiction because under section 2 of Bombay Act No. XXXVI of 1947 offence punishable with imprisonment up to seven years, triable only by Sessions Court per Second Schedule to CrPC.

High Court Bench (Bavdekar and Chainani JJ.) differed: Bavdekar J. held Bombay Act unaffected; Chainani J. held Central Act LII of 1950 prevailed. Matter heard by Chagla C.J. who agreed with Chainani J., found repugnancy under Article 254(2), dismissed revision on 20-1-1953.
Appeal to Supreme Court on certificate under Article 132(1).

legal_issues.text: Whether contravention of section 5(1) of the Bombay Food Grains Regulation of Movement and Sale Order, 1949, is punishable under section 2 of Bombay Act No. XXXVI of 1947 (imprisonment up to seven years, Sessions Court jurisdiction) or under section 7 of Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act as amended by Act No. LII of 1950 (maximum three years, Magistrate jurisdiction).

petitioner_arguments.text: Resident First Class Magistrate had no jurisdiction as offence punishable under section 2 Bombay Act XXXVI 1947 with imprisonment up to seven years, triable only by Sessions Court.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 2 Bombay Act No. XXXVI of 1947; Second Schedule CrPC

petitioner_arguments.text: Amendments to Essential Supplies Act in 1948, 1949, 1950 did not trench on Bombay Act XXXVI 1947.
Subject-matter of Bombay Act XXXVI 1947 exclusively in Provincial List, so section 107(2) Govt of India Act and Article 254(2) Constitution inapplicable.

respondent_arguments.text: Subsequent amendments to Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act, culminating in Act LII 1950, made Bombay Act XXXVI 1947 inoperative; maximum sentence three years under Central Act, Magistrate had jurisdiction.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act No. XXIV 1946 as amended by Act LII 1950 section 7; Article 254(2) Constitution; section 107(2) Govt of India Act

court_reasoning.text: Act No. LII of 1950 comprehensively covers punishment for offences under Essential Supplies Act, including enhanced punishment for hoarding foodgrains exceeding twice prescribed quantity up to seven years; covers same subject-matter as Bombay Act XXXVI 1947.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Section 7 of Act LII 1950 is legislation in respect of same matter as Bombay Act XXXVI 1947.

court_reasoning.text: Under Article 254(2), later Central law prevails over State law on concurrent matter if repugnant; no need for express repeal, implied repugnancy suffices as both cover punishment for contraventions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Punishment constitutes single subject-matter; cannot be split.

court_reasoning.text: Principle of implied repeal applies: later statute describing same offence with different punishment supersedes earlier.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Section 2 Bombay Act XXXVI 1947 cannot prevail against section 7 Essential Supplies Act as amended.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant's argument on exclusive Provincial List not permitted as not raised in leave petition under Article 132(1).

holdings.text: Section 2 of Bombay Act No. XXXVI of 1947 cannot prevail as against section 7 of the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act No. XXIV of 1946 as amended by Act No. LII of 1950.

precedents_cited.case_name: Attorney-General for Ontario v. Attorney-General for the Dominion
precedents_cited.relevance: Dominion Parliament could override Provincial legislation on concurrent matters but not expressly repeal.
Later statute describing offence created by previous one with different punishment repeals earlier.
Later statute varying punishment or procedure repeals earlier.

statutes_cited.name: Essential Supplies (Temporary Powers) Act, 1946
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to issue orders; punishment for contravention amended over time, final version in Act LII 1950 prevails.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Act No. XXXVI of 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Enhanced punishment to seven years for contraventions; repugnant to and superseded by Central Act.

statutes_cited.name: Essential Supplies (Temporary Powers) Amendment Act, 1950 (Act No. LII of 1950)
statutes_cited.relevance: Repealed and recast section 7; comprehensively covers punishments, prevails over State law.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Food Grains (Regulation of Movement and Sale) Order, 1949
Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Hearing on difference of opinion; jurisdiction based on punishment.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal; repugnancy, Central law prevails.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Pre-Constitution repugnancy rule, reproduced in Article 254(2).

outcome.summary: The appeal against the High Court judgment dismissing revision is dismissed. Conviction and sentence by Magistrate upheld as he had jurisdiction under section 7 of Essential Supplies Act as amended by Act LII 1950.

key_quotes.text: The point for determination is whether contravention of section 5(1) of the Bombay Food Grains Regulation of Movement and Sale Order, 1949, is punishable under section 2 of the Bombay Act No. XXXVI of 1947... or whether it is punishable under section 7 of the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act, as amended by Act No. LII of 1950.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Section 7 is thus a comprehensive code covering the entire field of punishment for offences under the Act, graded according to the commodities and to the character of the offence.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why Central Act covers same field as State Act.

key_quotes.text: We must accordingly hold that section 2 of Bombay Act No. XXXVI of 1947 cannot prevail as against section 7 of the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act No. XXIV of 1946 as amended by Act No. LII of 1950.
key_quotes.speaker: court
